name: Just Cause 2: Multiplayer Mod
description: JC2-MP is a project to bring multiplayer to Just Cause 2 in all of its magnificent glory. Imagine the chaos of normal Just Cause 2, then extending it out to dozens, hundreds, and even thousands of players.
minimum_requirements: OS: Microsoft Windows Vista (Windows XP is unsupported) Processor: Dual-core CPU with SSE3 (Athlon 64 X2 4200 / Pentium D 3GHz) Memory: 2GB System Memory Hard Drive: 10GB of free drive space Graphics: DX10 compatible graphics card with 256 MB of memory (Nvidia GeForce 8800 series/ ATI Radeon HD 2600 Pro) Sound: 100% DirectX 10 compatible sound card DirectX®: Microsoft DirectX 10
recommended_requirements: OS: Microsoft Windows Vista SP1 or Windows 7 Processor: Intel Core® 2 Duo 2.6 GHz or AMD Phenom X3 2.4GHz or equivalen Memory: 3GB system Memory Hard Drive:  Graphics: DX10 compatible graphics card with 512 MB of memory (Nvidia GeForce GTS 250 series/ ATI Radeon HD 5750 series)  Sound: 100% DirectX 10 compatible Dolby Digital 5.1 sound card DirectX®: Microsoft DirectX 10.1

I've been a fan of the main game Just Cause 2 and knew about the multiplayer mod for a while however only recently have I played it.  Only very few hours in, I'm enjoying every minute of it. Great way to kill some time, especially if you have a bunch of friends on the same server. I thought there might be issues with latency but for the servers I have connected to so far (Australian servers), it has been great.  Not all servers are the same, some are barebones with very few plugins etc on them for the game (derby, nametags, teleporting and a few others). Others can have race modes, stores (to buy weapons/vehicles/skins etc, some times these cost in-game money, sometimes they are completely free) and other funny things like boost modes for cars etc.

The first time I logged into the beta server all those months ago I was greeted with a flaming passenger jet hurtling past my screen. The lag was terrible, shots wouldn't hit anything and the rocket launcher was insanely overpowered. Yet, despite all this I had the most fun I'd had in a game for ages.  In the subsequent beta tests the lag became far less noticable and in the prerelease version it was down to no more than internet speed. One should approach this game as something akin to Planetside 2; but as one constant battlefield, with no commander and the ability to spawn a Hercules Jet whenever you want. This game is the embodiment of chaos, and I loved every second of it.

Ingredients:  •4 russet potatoes, peeled •1 lb ground beef •1/2 tsp cayenne •1 tsp paprika •1 tsp cumin powder •Oil for frying •Salt & pepper •1 cup shredded cheddar or Mexican cheese mix •1 tomato, seeded and chopped •Sour cream  Quick Guacamole •1 avocado, pitted and peel removed •Juice of 1 lime •1 tsp fresh cilantro, chopped + more for garnish •1/8 cup red onion, chopped •1/2 jalapeno, seeded and chopped  Directions:        Report this ad    1.Cut potatoes into French fry lengths (a mandoline comes in handy here). Add to a large bowl and fill with enough cold water to cover the fries. Refrigerate for about 30 minutes to 1 hour. 2.While the potatoes are soaking, cook the ground beef. Warm a medium skillet over medium-high heat. When the pan is hot, add the ground beef along with the cayenne, paprika, cumin, ¼ tsp salt and ¼ black pepper. Cook, breaking up the meat so it doesn’t form large clumps, until browned and cooked through. Keep warm and set aside. 3.To make the quick guacamole, smash the avocado in a small bowl with the back of your form until smooth. Stir in jalapeno, red onion, cilantro, salt, pepper and lime juice. Cover and set aside. 4.Pour oil into a dutch oven or heavy bottomed pot until it is 3' deep. Heat over medium heat until the temperature reaches 375 degrees. Drain potatoes and dry completely with paper towels. Fry the potatoes, working in small batches, until crisp and golden. Remove to a paper towel lined plate to drain. Season immediately with salt. 5.Add the French fries to a cast iron skillet. Top with the cooked ground beef and shredded cheese. Turn on oven broiler to high and broil until the cheese is melted and bubbling, approximately 2 to 3 minutes. Remove from oven, top with chopped tomato, guacamole, and sour cream. Sprinkle with extra fresh cilantro and serve immediately.

Let me start with the negatives first: Con's: - Can crash a lot (turn of 'Decals' in the options menu to avoid most of them) - Taking over towns is absolutely repetitive - Huge open world, but it feels empty sometimes  Pro's: - You can blow stuff up! - You want to blow stuff up! - Plenty of towns to blow stuff up! - Grappling is fun - Plenty of mods available - Huge open world map to explore - Easter eggs - Action packed  Don't take this game too seriously and you'll have lots of fun. :-) Don't pass this one by, the price of this game is ridiculously low for what you get in return.  10/10

This mod is why I bought JC2 on PC, as I already owned it on Xbox 360. Unfortunately, I didn't do enough looking into this mod before I bought the PC version. It's not a bad mod and can be fun to play, but perhaps understandably so, there are no NPCs. I was hoping for like a campaign co-op feature but it's not there. Every server pretty much just for pvp. One major complaints that I have is that in the mod, there is a wingsuit but they didn't add the ability to activate it using a controller. You HAVE to use the keyboard. This is a problem for me as I've always used a 360 controller when I played this so using a keyboard would be like me switching to a PS4. It'd take me hours to get used to it and imo it's not worth it. Unfortunately again, most players use the wingsuit, usually to escape unfavorable pvp conditions and once they're flying, their speed literally rivals that of a jet in the game, no joke. Overall though, these issues are mostly ones personal to me, just so you know these things going in, I still think you should get the mod. It is free after all.

This is what hell and utter chaos means.  Just Cause 2 is a cheap, huge, and rather ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ game were you do tons of stuff, but spend most of the game blowing things up. Now think: Would it be fun to do that, with 10.000 other players?  Oh boy, if it was, and still is. When this got released on Steam, some servers where 100% full, and some of them had the limit of 10.000 players. Now stop there for a second and think, because THIS is what GTA Online should have been. Not that crappy 16 limit-players ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.  There are no rules in this game. The map is huge, and it's filled with complete war-zones, with over 500 players killing each other for no reason. There are races, dance parties, and even Limo-demolition-derby matches. F#CKING LIMO-DEMOLITION-DERBIES, DO I NEED TO SAY MORE!?  This game turns into the best game ever when you actually get friends to play it with. You can go arround, with 10 people hanging of a combat helicopter, while the driver rains hell on the people under you, while you and your friends just shoot each other in the face. You can surf police-cars that reach 800km/h. You can even crash in the Lost island, and try to survive while one of you guys plays as a Sniping camping hunter.  Proper reviews can't review this mess. But I'll tell you, it's a hell of a mess, the one you end up loving. I would keep it playing, if my good computer didn't exploded, and my back-up one didn't had so much FPS-Drops with the game. The Multiplayer is free, and even if it needs the actual game, the game itself is cheap as ♥♥♥♥. There's no excuse to join the madness, and crash tanks into people's faces.

This multiplayer mod is just... madness. On most servers the only way to acquire money is to win races (or place as close to first as possible) and the races themselves are hilarious and quite challenging. There's something really funny about being in a race where other players are flipping through the air and exploding all around you while you're trying to dodge some trees or a nasty looking bump in the road. It's kind of intense.   You will run into glitches galore, and the occational CTD, but the people that made this mod are a very small team - the fact that this mod works at all is pretty amazing.  I would recommend Just Cause 2 without missing a beat - it's one of my favorite games of all time. The multiplayer is fun and free so I would recommend you check that out, too.

A great concept and a very decent attempt when building on something you have very little in the way of guts to prod about. I was a part of the open betas and I had a lot of fun with the factions system. When the guiding principle of this game is its namesake ' Just 'cos ', it really helps to be doing the crazy things with likeminded people. Be a roving militia or a pirate. Be a taxi cabby. Be an airline passenger. Race in a derby or participate in skydiving competitions. Or sit on a grassy knoll and snipe people who use the teleport function.  Just one question: In the release trailer, with the sniper taking out the helicopter, the chatter on the left was redacted. How much  racism and Ponies  did the community have to belch out in order for this to happen? Because I was there for a lot of it, and my faith in humanity took quite a hit before I learned how to hide the chatter proper.  In closing, the system is great and it brings a lot of emergent gameplay potential and frenzied excitement to what is otherwise a pretty lonely game. Just keep the chatter  off  and do not interact with  a single soul  unless you know them (and even then, get Ventrilo or Mumble). Because by-and-large, JC2MP citizens are like YouTube commenters, they're all entitled to their opinions and their anuses, and they tend to exercise both without discretion.

This is what hell and utter chaos means.  Just Cause 2 is a cheap, huge, and rather ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ game were you do tons of stuff, but spend most of the game blowing things up. Now think: Would it be fun to do that, with 10.000 other players?  Oh boy, if it was, and still is. When this got released on Steam, some servers where 100% full, and some of them had the limit of 10.000 players. Now stop there for a second and think, because THIS is what GTA Online should have been. Not that crappy 16 limit-players ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.  There are no rules in this game. The map is huge, and it's filled with complete war-zones, with over 500 players killing each other for no reason. There are races, dance parties, and even Limo-demolition-derby matches. F#CKING LIMO-DEMOLITION-DERBIES, DO I NEED TO SAY MORE!?  This game turns into the best game ever when you actually get friends to play it with. You can go arround, with 10 people hanging of a combat helicopter, while the driver rains hell on the people under you, while you and your friends just shoot each other in the face. You can surf police-cars that reach 800km/h. You can even crash in the Lost island, and try to survive while one of you guys plays as a Sniping camping hunter.  Proper reviews can't review this mess. But I'll tell you, it's a hell of a mess, the one you end up loving. I would keep it playing, if my good computer didn't exploded, and my back-up one didn't had so much FPS-Drops with the game. The Multiplayer is free, and even if it needs the actual game, the game itself is cheap as ♥♥♥♥. There's no excuse to join the madness, and crash tanks into people's faces.

All effort is appreciated, but this is not a cooperative sandbox, this is an unpopulated slaughterfest.

So, here's something fun I discovered that I wish I had known before getting JC2 just for the multiplayer:  There are no NPCs in the multiplayer mod. No cars driving around, no soldiers, nothing. Apparently, according to the mods, 'it's impossible to synch the NPCs' and the best you can do is download a script that may or may not make the game insta-crash.  Damn. I wasn't aware that synching NPCs across two players was an impossible feat! I mean, it's not like in any multiplayer game before or since could have NPCs or cars driving around between people! Obviously in Gmod when I spawn an NPC it doesn't show up to my friend because it can't synch! Obviously, there has never been a co-op game that wasn't completely desolate because it is just impossible to have AI synch up between two or more players. Or hey, in World of Warcraft, it's PVP *ONLY* because there is just no way to synch the AI together between more than one player so you can't fight AI together with your raid party, right? ........  Yeah, big ♥♥♥♥ing thumbs down for this crap.

It's sort of fun, and it's free, so there's no point not picking it up. But the zaniness of playing with other people quickly tires as you realise it has the same problem the singleplayer campaign had: repetition. Other games keep things fresh, oddly enough, by removing sandbox elements and tightly controlling what players can do, so that they learn to do it in new ways. This just makes you realise there's only so many road races, random shootouts, and airport disaster collisions you can be involved in before the game is dull again.
